title: University Mathematics
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1018.
description: This course is designed for students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of one-variable calculus at a general level for the studies in science or engineering. The course places special emphasis on conceptual understanding and computational techniques.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to:•  Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in one variable calculus•  Logically prove basic statements in one variable calculus•  Calculate various differential quantities and solve problems using one variable calculus•  Apply the methods of one variable calculus to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics•  Appreciate the rationale and impact of one variable calculus to human development in science and technology.
syllabus: Limits, derivatives, linear approximation, curve sketching, mean value theorem, L'Hospital's rule, Taylor’s theorem, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration.
recommended_readings: •  Calculus of One Variable, K.E. Hirst, Springer-Verlag •  Edwards and Penny, Calculus: Early Transcendentals•  Thomas and Finney, Calculus and Analytical Geometry

title: Honours University Mathematics
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1010. Co-requisite: MATH1038.
description: This course is designed for MATH major students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of one-variable calculus at an advanced level. The course places special emphasis on theoretical foundations and techniques for computations.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to: •  Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in one variable calculus.•  Logically prove basic statements in one variable calculus.•  Calculate various differential quantities and solve problems using one variable calculus•  Apply the methods of one variable calculus to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics.•  Appreciate the rationale and impact of one variable calculus to human development in science and technology.
syllabus: Limits, derivatives, linear approximation, curve sketching, mean value theorem, L'Hospital's rule, Taylor’s theorem, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration; constructions of certain basic functions of one variable, and mechanisms of the proofs of various theorems as appropriate
recommended_readings: -  Calculus of One Variable, K.E. Hirst, Springer-Verlag-  Edwards and Penny, Calculus: Early Transcendentals-  Thomas and Finney, Calculus and Analytical Geometry

title: General Mathematics
description: This course is designed to give students a solid foundation for learning calculus and other areas of mathematics in engineering.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to • understand the basics of functions. • recognize different types of elementary functions, their graphs, know their properties and solve related equations. • understand topics in vectors, series and power series, complex numbers and probability and perform related computations. • develop a solid foundation to study mathematics in other areas of engineering.
syllabus: Sets and functions, polynomial and rational functions, trigonometric functions, exponential and logarithmic functions, series and power series, complex numbers, vectors and probability.
recommended_readings: Michael Sullivan, Michael Sullivan III, Precalculus: enhanced with graphing utilities, 6th Edition, Pearson, 2013.

title: Linear Algebra I
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1038.
description: This course is designed for students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of linear algebra. The course emphasizes the fundamental principles, reasoning of mathematics and also applications, but generality instead of particular usage will be the focus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to-  define and distinguish the usual concepts used in linear algebra-  logically prove basic statements in linear algebra-  solve problems using linear algebra, including those in an abstract setting-  apply the methods of linear algebra to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics-  appreciate the rationale and impact of linear algebra to human development in science and technology
syllabus: Set notations; system of linear equations, Gaussian elimination; matrices, determinants; Euclidean vector spaces, subspaces, linear span, linear independence, bases and dimension; eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization; orthogonality, Gram-Schmidt process.
recommended_readings: -  Leon, Linear Algebra with Applications-  Johnson, Riess, Arnold, Introduction to Linear Algebra

title: Honours Linear Algebra I
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1030. Co-requisite: MATH1018.
description: This serves as the first course on linear algebra for MATH major students. The course emphasizes the fundamental concepts and principles in linear algebra, and focuses on rigorous reasoning of mathematical statements, computational techniques as well as applications.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to-  define and distinguish the usual concepts used in linear algebra-  logically prove basic statements in linear algebra and understand ideas behind the proofs of theorems-  solve problems using linear algebra, including those in an abstract setting-  apply the methods of linear algebra to standard problems in physics, engineering, or business economics-  appreciate the rationale and impact of linear algebra to human development in science and technology
syllabus: Set notations; system of linear equations, Gaussian elimination; matrices, determinants; Euclidean and abstract vector spaces, subspaces, linear span, linear independence, bases and dimension; definition and examples of linear transformations; eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization; orthogonality, Gram-Schmidt process.
recommended_readings: -  G. Strang: Linear algebra and applications-  S. Friedberg, A. Insel, L. Spence: Linear algebra

title: Foundation of Modern Mathematics
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1058. Pre-requisite: MATH1010 or MATH1018 or (Grade B or above in MATH1510 or MATH1520). Co-requisite: MATH1030 or MATH1038 or ENGG1410 or ESTR1004 or ENGG1120 or ESTR1005.
description: This course introduces rigorous mathematical reasoning, and proofs. The use of logic in mathematics and various methods of proof will be illustrated by concrete examples from a variety of topics in mathematics. Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to:  • Read and write mathematical statements.  • Prove simple mathematical results in various topics, such as number theory, inequalities, polynomials, complex numbers, set language.  • Understand the basic properties of number systems, and infinite sets.
syllabus: Mathematical statements, sets, relations and functions, infinite sets and countability, natural numbers and induction, integers, rational, real and complex numbers, elementary inequalities.
recommended_readings: • Binmore, K.G.: Logic, Sets and Numbers • Bloch E.D.: Proofs and Fundamentals: a first course in abstract mathematics  • Briggs W., Bryan, G.H. Walker G.: The Tutorial Algebra (Vol. I, II)  • Halmos P.R.: Naïve Set Theory.  • Leung K.T., Chan D.L.C.: Elementary Set Theory • Leung K.T., Cheung P.H.: Fundamental Concepts of Mathematics

title: Honours Foundation of Modern Mathematics
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH1050. 
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] B- or above in each of MATH1018, MATH1038. [Alternative 2] A- or above in each of MATH1010, 1030.
description: This course introduces rigorous mathematical reasoning, and proofs. The use of logic in mathematics and various methods of proof will be illustrated by concrete examples from a variety of topics in mathematics. Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to:  • Read and write mathematical statements.  • Prove rigorously simple mathematical results in various topics, such as number theory, inequalities, polynomials, complex numbers, set theory.  • Understand (including through the axiomatic approach) the basic properties of number systems, and infinite sets.

Walker G.: The Tutorial Algebra (Vol. I, II)  • Halmos P.R.: Naïve Set Theory.  • Kadison L, Kromann M.T.: Projective Geometry and Modern Algebra • Leung K.T., Chan D.L.C.: Elementary Set Theory  • Leung K.T., Cheung P.H.: Fundamental Concepts of Mathematics

title: Calculus for Engineers
description: This course is designed for engineering students who need to acquire skills in calculus as a crash introduction to the mathematics used in engineering. The course emphasizes on the technique of computation without theoretical discussion. Students are expected to have mathematics background equivalent to HKDSE with Extended Module I or II.
outcome: Students will learn the aspects of single variable Calculus that apply to engineering applications. They will also have an exposure to some applications of single variable Calculus in engineering and physics.
syllabus: 1. Transcendental functions (exponential, logarithm, trigonometric and their inverses). 2. Curves represented by parametric equations. 3. Differentiation in single variable calculus (basic rules, implicit differentiation, rate of change, approximation, L’Hospital's Rule, extreme values and curve sketching). 4. Vector valued functions and their differentiation rules. 5. Integration in single variable calculus (definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration, area and volume of revolution).  6. Series (Taylor expansion, Taylor and Maclaurin series, techniques involving power series and Taylor’s theorem).
recommended_readings: • T. Croft, R. Davison: Mathematics for Engineers, A modern interactive approach, 2nd ed., Prentice Hall • C. Edwards, D. Penney: Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Matrix Version, 6th ed., Prentice Hall

title: University Mathematics for Applications
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1010/1018.
description: This course is designed for students who need to acquire the knowledge and skills of one-variable calculus at a general level for the studies in business, economics, social and life sciences. The course emphasizes the methods and techniques of computation and their applications, with appropriate discussions on theoretical foundation.
outcome: Students are able to - Define and distinguish the usual concepts used in calculus - Calculate differential and integral quantities in one variable calculus - Apply calculus to solve problems in business, economics, social and life sciences - Appreciate the rationale and impact of one variable calculus to human development in all sectors of society
syllabus: Permutation, combination and simple probabilities, Logarithm and exponential functions, limit, continuity, derivative, rules of differentiations, inflexion and convexity, optimization, applications to demand, utility and revenue, integration and area, applications in ordinary differential equations and probability.
recommended_readings: - Barnett et al, Applied Calculus for Business, Economics, Life Sciences, and Social Sciences - Hoffmann, Bradley, Applied Calculus for Business, Economics, Social Sciences and Life Sciences

title: Basic Mathematics for Business and Social Sciences
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1010/1018, MATH1030/1038 or MATH2xxx or above.
description: This course equips students with the necessary basic mathematics for applications in business and social sciences. It is particularly suitable for those without much mathematics training in high school. Concepts will be introduced by examples in these disciplines.
outcome: Students are able to: • Acquire mathematical skills beyond school level. • Apply elementary mathematics to solve simple problems in business and social sciences. • Appreciate the rationale and impact of mathematics to human development in business and social sciences.
syllabus: Topics include: linear equations, matrices, linear programming, counting and probability, mathematics of finance, modelling in mathematics.
recommended_readings: • Biggs N, Anthony M: Mathematics for Economics and Finance • Liall M L, Greenwell R N, Ritchey N P: Finite Mathematics and Calculus with Applications.

title: University Mathematics for Financial Studies
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH1010.
description: This course is designed for students who wish to specialize in mathematics related financial studies. It is especially suitable for those who have a mathematics background similar to that of HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module I or II. The students are to acquire further cognition and stronger skills from their original training. It leads to the command of knowledge and operation of higher algebra. By this course, the students will have a smooth transition into studying the essential mathematics for financial studies.
outcome: Students are able to: • Write mathematical argument inductively and deductively • Perform matrix operations, calculate determinants, find inverses and solve equations in such context • Perform usual work involving partial differentiation and multiple integrals  • Appreciate the rationale and impact of pure mathematics to human development in business and technology.
syllabus: Foundation of mathematics, matrix algebra and linear equations, calculus of several variable
recommended_readings: • Kolman and Hill, Introductory Linear Algebra with Applications • Thomas, Weir, and Hass, Thomas’ Calculus  • Edwards and Penny, Calculus: Early Transcendentals

title: Methods of Matrices and Linear Algebra
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH1030/1038.
description: This course is providing a matrix oriented approach for an elementary introduction to linear algebra. It emphasizes on the methods and techniques. It builds for students the basic understanding and calculation skills on matrix operations, systems of linear equations, determinants, orthogonality, eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Linear transformations may be touched on. It is particularly suitable for students without much mathematics background and intended to be major is Statistics, Economics, Business, and Life Sciences. Students in Social Sciences may also benefit.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  - Perform essential calculations in matrices, determinants, and linear systems; - Use these calculations in the context of certain business and scientific applications; - Realize the importance of linear algebra in a broad spectrum of subject areas; - Prepare for undergraduate studies requiring statistical knowledge.
syllabus: Matrix and vector notations, systems of linear equations and Gaussian elimination, linear independence of row/column vectors; matrix operations and inverse, cofactor expansion and properties of determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, orthogonal vectors and Gram-Schmidt process, orthogonal projection and least-square method, subspaces in Euclidean space, basis and dimension, matrix transformations.
recommended_readings: L.E. Spence, A.J. Insel, S.H. Friedberg. Elementary Linear Algebra, Pearson. C.H. Edwards, D.E. Penney. Elementary Linear Algebra, Pearson. B. Kolman, D. Hill. Elementary Linear Algebra with Applications, Pearson. H. Anton. Elementary Linear Algebra, Wiley.

title: Advanced Calculus I
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH2018. Pre-requisite: MATH1010/1018 or (Grade B or above in MATH1510 or MATH1520). Co-requisite: MATH1030/1038 or MATH1050/1058.
description: This course is intended to introduce the basics of the calculus of functions of several variables. Topics include: vectors, geometry of Euclidean spaces, curves, limits, partial derivatives, differentiability, chain rule, first and second derivative test, maximum and minimum, Taylor polynomials, Lagrange multipliers, implicit function theorem.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students understand the basic concepts and applications of the calculus of functions of several variables, including vectors, functions of several variables, partial derivatives and their applications, and extremum problems.
syllabus: vectors, geometry of Euclidean spaces, curves, limits, partial derivatives, differentiability, chain rule, first and second derivative test, maximum and minimum, Taylor polynomials, Lagrange multipliers, implicit function theorem.
recommended_readings: - T. Au, Differential Multivariable Calculus, Asian Customized Edition, McGraw Hill - G. B. Thomas, M. D. Weir and J. Hass, Thomas' Calculus, Pearson - H. Anton, I. Bivens and S. Davis, Anton’s Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Wiley - C. H. Edwards and D. E. Penney, Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Prentice Hall

title: Honours Advanced Calculus I
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH2010. Co-requisite: MATH1050/1058.
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] Grade B- or above in each of MATH1018, MATH1038. [Alternative 2] Grade A- or above in each of MATH1010, 1030.
description: This course is intended to introduce the basics of the calculus of functions of several variables. Topics include: vectors, geometry of Euclidean spaces, curves, limits, partial derivatives, differentiability, chain rule, first and second derivative test, maximum and minimum, Taylor polynomials, Lagrange multipliers, implicit function theorem.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students understand the basic concepts and applications of the calculus of functions of several variables, including vectors, functions of several variables, partial derivatives and their applications, and extremum problems, as well as the ideas behind the proofs of the theorems.
syllabus: vectors, geometry of Euclidean spaces, curves, limits, partial derivatives, differentiability, chain rule, first and second derivative test, maximum and minimum, Taylor polynomials, Lagrange multipliers, implicit function theorem.
recommended_readings: - T. Au, Differential Multivariable Calculus, Asian Customized Edition, McGraw Hill - G. B. Thomas, M. D. Weir and J. Hass, Thomas' Calculus, Pearson - H. Anton, I. Bivens and S. Davis, Anton’s Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Wiley - C. H. Edwards and D. E. Penney, Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Prentice Hall

title: Advanced Calculus II
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH2028. 
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] MATH2010/2018. [Alternative 2] (ENGG1410 or ESTR1004 or ENGG1130 or ESTR1006) and MATH1050/1058.
description: This is a continuation of MATH2010. The following topics will be discussed: multiple integrals: double integrals, areas, volumes, surface areas, change of variables; vector analysis: line integrals, surface integrals, Green theorem, divergence theorem, Stokes theorem.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students understand the theory and the applications of multiple integrals. These include line integrals, multiple integrals, surface integrals and applications to vector analysis.
syllabus: Multiple integrals: double integrals, areas, volumes, surface areas, change of variables; vector analysis: line integrals, surface integrals, Green theorem, divergence theorem, Stokes theorem.
recommended_readings: - H. Anton, I. Bivens and S. Davis, Anton’s Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Wiley - T. Au, Differential Multivariable Calculus, Asian Customized Edition, McGraw Hill - C. H. Edwards and D. E. Penney, Calculus, Early Transcendentals, Prentice Hall - G. B. Thomas, M. D. Weir and J. Hass, Thomas' Calculus, Pearson

title: Honours Advanced Calculus II
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH2020.
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] Grade B- or above in each of MATH1058, MATH2018. [Alternative 2] Grade A- or above in each of MATH1050, 2010.
description: This is a continuation of MATH2018. The following topics will be discussed: multiple integrals in n-dimensions: areas and n-volumes, surface areas, volumes of submanifolds and hypersurfaces in n-space, change of variables; vector analysis: line integrals, surface integrals, integration on submanifolds, Green theorem, divergence theorem and Stokes theorem in n-dimensions.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Linear Algebra II
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH2048. Pre-requisite: (MATH1030/1038 or ENGG1410 or ESTR1004 or ENGG1120 or ESTR1005) and MATH1050/1058.
description: This is a continuation of MATH1030. Topics include: abstract vector spaces, linear transformations, matrix representation, nullity and rank, properties of determinants, diagonalization, Cayley-Hamilton theorem, inner product spaces, normal and self-adjoint operators, canonical forms, spectral theorem. Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: We expect students to understand more advanced topics in linear algebra: abstract vector spaces and linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, canonical forms of matrices and linear transformations, inner product spaces, and spectral theorems. Students are expected to understand the ideas underlying the concepts and write mathematical proofs.
syllabus: Abstract vector spaces, subspaces, sum and direct sum, span and linear independence, basis and dimension, linear transformations and their matrix representations, null space and range, rank-nullity theorem, change of basis formula, invertibility and isomorphism, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization, invariant subspaces and Cayley-Hamilton theorem; inner product spaces, orthogonality, adjoint of an operator, normal and self-adjoint operators, Jordan canonical forms, spectral theorems and applications.
recommended_readings: - S. Friedberg, A. Insel and L. Spence: Linear Algebra - P. Halmos: Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces

title: Honours Linear Algebra II
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH2040. 
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] B- or above in each of MATH1058, MATH2018. [Alternative 2] A- or above in each of MATH1030, 1050.
description: This is a continuation of MATH1038. Topics include: abstract vector spaces, linear transformations, matrix representation, nullity and rank, properties of determinants, diagonalization, Cayley-Hamilton theorem, inner product spaces, normal and self-adjoint operators, unitary and orthogonal operators, bilinear forms, dual spaces, canonical forms, spectral theorem. Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Mathematical Analysis I
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH2055 or MATH2058. Pre-requisite: [MATH1010/1018 (or Grade B or above in MATH1510 or MATH1520)], and MATH1050/1058.
description: This course is intended to provide conceptual understanding in the theory of functions of one real variable. Topics include: real numbers, real valued functions, set notations; limits of sequences, convergence, Bolzano-Weierstrass; limits of functions, continuous functions, uniform continuity.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: We emphasize the rigorous epsilon-delta approach to analysis, which is crucial for a solid study of analysis. After taking and passing this course, a student is expected - to understand the axioms of the real number system (constructions such as the Dedekind cuts are not necessary), - to know the basic properties of countable and uncountable sets (must know that real numbers and irrational numbers are uncountable) and the statement of the continuum hypothesis,  - to familiarize with the concept of limits of sequences and functions, and - to know the concept of continuity and uniform continuity for functions on the real line as well as relevant results
syllabus: Real numbers, real valued functions, set notations; limits of sequences, convergence, Bolzano-Weierstrass; limits of functions, continuous functions, uniform continuity.
recommended_readings: - Introduction to Real Analysis, 3rd Edition, by R.G. Bartle and D.R. Sherbert, John-Wiley and Sons, NY - Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 3rd Edition, by W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, International Editions - Functions of Several Variables, 2nd Edition, by W. Fleming, Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York - Mathematical Analysis I and II, Fudan University, Commerce Press

title: Honours Mathematical Analysis I
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH2050 or MATH2055. 
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] B- or above in each of MATH1058, MATH2018. [Alternative 2] A- or above in each of MATH1050, 2010.
description: This course is intended to provide conceptual understanding in the theory of functions of one or more real variables. Topics include: real numbers, real valued functions, set notations; limits of sequences (including limsup and liminf), convergence, Bolzano-Weierstrass, infinite series; limits of functions, continuous functions, uniform continuity.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Mathematical Analysis II
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH2055 or MATH2068. Pre-requisite: MATH2050/2058.
description: This is a continuation of MATH2050. Topics include: differentiability, mean-value theorem, Taylor theorem, convexity; integrability, fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals; power series, radius of convergence, series for elementary functions; infinite series, convergence and divergence, rearrangement; sequence and series of functions.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: After taking and passing this course a student will be able (1) to know the properties of differentiable functions and convex functions, (2) to use Darboux sums to study Riemann integrable functions and learn the Taylor formula with remainder, (3) to understand the fundamental theorems of calculus which relate integration to differentiation, and (4) to know basic tests for convergence of infinite series and functions, and (5) to know how the elementary functions including the exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions are rigorously defined. In (1)-(3) he/she should master those examples and counterexamples which illustrate the applicability of various theorems.
syllabus: Differentiability, mean-value theorem, Taylor theorem, convexity; integrability, fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals; power series, radius of convergence, series for elementary functions; infinite series, convergence and divergence, rearrangement; sequence and series of functions.
recommended_readings: - Introduction to Real Analysis, 3rd Edition, by R.G. Bartle and D.R. Sherbert, John-Wiley and Sons, NY - Principles of Mathematical Analysis, 3rd Edition, by W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, International Editions - Functions of Several Variables, 2nd Edition, by W. Fleming, Undergraduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York - Mathematical Analysis I and II, Fudan University, Commerce Press

title: Honours Mathematical Analysis II
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH2055 or MATH2060. 
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] B- or above in each of MATH2028, MATH2058. [Alternative 2] A- or above in each of MATH2020, 2050.
description: This is a continuation of MATH2058. Topics include: differentiability in one or higher dimensions, mean-value theorem, Taylor theorem, convexity; integrability in one or higher dimensions, fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals, Fubini’s theorem for double series and continuous functions; power series, radius of convergence, series for elementary functions, real analyticity; sequence and series of functions, uniform convergence.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Algebraic Structures
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH2078. Pre-requisite: (MATH1030/1038 or ENGG1120 or ESTR1005) and MATH1050/1058.
description: This course is intended as an introduction to modern abstract algebra and the way of algebraic thinking in advanced mathematics. The course focuses on basic algebraic concepts which arise in various areas of advanced mathematics, and emphasizes on the underlying algebraic structures which are common to various concrete mathematical examples. Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to: 1. define basic algebraic structures, 2. understand algebraic properties and their consequences for various algebraic structures, 3. recognize the underlying algebraic structures which are common to various concrete mathematical examples.
syllabus: Groups including cyclic groups, permutation groups and dihedral groups, subgroups, cosets and the Theorem of Lagrange, group homomorphisms; rings including the ring of integers, polynomial rings and Boolean algebras, integral domains, fields, ring homomorphisms, subrings, ideals and quotient rings; examples of field extensions and finite fields.
recommended_readings: - J. Landin, An Introduction to Algebraic Structures, Dover - Serge Lang, Undergraduate Algebra, Springer

title: Honours Algebraic Structures
requirements:
Not for students who have taken MATH2070. 
Pre-requisite: [Alternative 1] B- or above in each of MATH1058, MATH2018. [Alternative 2] A- or above in each of MATH1030, 1050.
description: This course is intended as an introduction to modern abstract algebra and the way of algebraic thinking in advanced mathematics. The course focuses on basic algebraic concepts which arise in various areas of advanced mathematics, and emphasizes on the underlying algebraic structures which are common to various concrete mathematical examples.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Mathematics Laboratory II
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH 2210 or 2220. Co-requisite: (MATH1010/1018) and (MATH1030/1038) and (MATH1050/1058).
description: This course is intended to teach numerical computing, symbolic computing, and graphical visualization through the use of mathematical and computational software so as to familiarize the students with computing skills.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to use MATLAB to (a) perform direct mathematical and matrix computations (b) develop simple algorithms (c) perform tasks involving modeling, simulation, data analysis, and visualization
syllabus: Topics: Mathematics operations, Arrays and Matrices, Relational and Logical Operations, Control flow, Curve fitting, Numerical Analysis, 2D and 3D Graphics, File control, Toolboxes, Symbolic Calculations
recommended_readings: - MATLAB: an introduction with applications by Amos Gilat - MATLAB: a practical introduction to programming and problem solving by Stormy Attaway - A concise introduction to MATLAB by William J. Palm III

title: Complex Variables with Applications
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH2020/2028.
description: This course is to introduce the basic properties of complex functions and analytic functions and to illustrate the important use of these theories to other branches of mathematics and sciences. Topics include: complex numbers; limits, continuity and derivatives, Cauchy-Riemann equations, analytic functions; elementary functions; mapping by elementary functions; Contours integrals, Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Cauchy integral formula, Morera’s theorem, maximum moduli of functions, the fundamental theorem of algebra; Taylor series and Laurent’s series; residues and poles, evaluation of infinite real integrals.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are able to: 1. Define and recognize complex differentiable functions and analytic functions. 2. State the basic properties of analytic functions and major theories about these functions related to contour integration. 3. Work out the local properties at zeros or singularities of analytic functions by series or integrals. 4. Apply residue theory to evaluate real integrals.
syllabus: Complex numbers; limits, continuity and derivatives, Cauchy-Riemann equations, analytic functions; elementary functions; mapping by elementary functions; Contours integrals, Cauchy-Goursat theorem, Cauchy integral formula, Morera’s theorem, maximum moduli of functions, the fundamental theorem of algebra; Taylor series and Laurent’s series; residues and poles, evaluation of infinite real integrals.
recommended_readings: - J. W. Brown and R. V. Churchill, Complex Variables and Applications, McGraw Hill - E. B. Saff and A. D. Snider, Fundamental of Complex Analysis, Prentice Hall - T. Needham, Visual Complex Analysis, Cambridge University Press

title: Advanced Calculus (I) for Physical Science and Engineering
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH1010/1018 or (Grade B or above in MATH1510 or MATH1520).
description: This course covers the most common techniques and methods of multivariable differential calculus, with an emphasis on examples of three variables. Reasoning and theory will be discussed but not in the most rigorous way. Topics include Euclidean space, Curves and its tangent frame, limits and differentiation of functions, extremum problems.Advisory: Suitable for major in Physics, Earth System Sciences, most Engineering, and Chemistry.
outcome: Students are able to deal with problems involving calculus of 3-variable functions according to the basic knowledge and principles. Methods include vector manipulation, 3-variable functions, partial derivatives and their applications, and extremum problems.
syllabus: Vectors and algebraic properties of Euclidean 3-space, matrices and Linear systems, linear and quadratic objects in space. Curves, speed and velocity, tangents and normal, acceleration and curvature, curvilinear motions. Limits of 3-variable functions, partial and directional differentiation, Chain Rules, differential and matrix approximation, multivariable differentiability; maximum and minimum, Lagrange multiplier, multivariable Taylor Formula and critical point analysis, implicit differentiation. Methods and Applications of ODE, separable equations, first order equations, second order equations with constant coefficients.
required_readings: - Thomas, G. B., Weir, M. and Hass, J. Thomas’ Calculus: Multivariable, Chapters 12 – 14. Pearson. - Leon, Steve., Linear Algebra with Applications, Chapters 1 – 2. Pearson.

title: Quantitative Methods for Earth and Environmental Sciences
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH2010/2018, MATH2020/2028 or MATH2530. Pre-requisite: MATH1010/1018 or (Grade B or above in MATH1510 or MATH1520).
description: This course provides an introduction to the various mathematical techniques necessary for studying the Earth System and Environmental Sciences. Topics include: Foundational matrix methods, vectors and tensors as well as their linear transformations; methods for solving ordinary differential equations with examples in geochemistry, environmental chemistry and ecology; partial differentiation, line integrals and multiple integrals, and their applications in geophysics, atmospheric and ocean sciences; methods and intuition of vector calculus for use in mechanics with a focus on environmental systems.
outcome: 1. review the basic mathematical methods the student learnt and have a more in-depth understanding of their roles and applications in Earth System and Environmental Sciences; 2. learn competent mathematical skills to formulate realistic models for fundamental processes associated with the atmosphere, biosphere, geosphere and hydrosphere, solve the physical problems by mathematical techniques, and interpret the results physically; 3. gain a sense of the relative importance of different physical and chemical quantities involved in Earth and environmental processes, and hence take appropriate approximations in mathematical derivations; 4. gain a coherent picture of how various mathematical methods can be integrated in describing coupled processes in the environment and solving the problems; 5. appreciate the important role of mathematics in Earth system and environmental sciences, as well as its applications in related areas; 6. generalize the applications of the mathematical methods you learnt in lectures to new situations.
syllabus: 1. Vectors, Matrices and Applications  Vectors in R^2 " or " R^3, their representations in rectangular, cylindrical and spherical coordinates, System of Linear Equations and Gaussian Elimination, Matrices and its action on vectors, Orthogonal Matrix, Determinants. 2. Transcendental Functions Logarithmic and Exponential Functions, Trigonometric and Hyperbolic Functions, their expressions in terms of one complex variable. 3. Ordinary Differential Equations – Methods and Applications First-order Differential Equations; Second-order Differential Equations: separable equations, Equations with Constant Coefficients, The Integrating Factor Method for Homogeneous Differential Equations; Finding particular solutions for inhomogeneous Differential Equations; Examples in geochronology, geochemistry, environmental chemistry, ecology and public health 4. A Quick Study of Differential Calculus Partial and directional derivatives, gradient and total differentials (rate of change and linear approximation), Chain Rule (including versions in terms of matrix multiplication) 5. Multiple Integration Double Integrals in Rectangular Coordinates and Polar Coordinates; Triple Integrals in Rectangular, Cylindrical and Spherical Coordinates; Jacobian of Transformation, Surface Area and Integrals over a Curved Surface. Applications in gravity and planetary science. 6. Methods in Vector Calculus Gradient, Divergence and Curl; Vector Operations in Various Coordinates; Physical Examples: Field Flux and Divergence Theorem, Circulation and Stokes’ Theorem, with applications in the fluid mechanics of the ocean and atmosphere, seismology, geodynamics and hydrology.
recommended_readings: 1. M L Boas, Mathematical Methods in the Physical Sciences, Wiley, 1983 2. W E Boyce and R C DiPrima, Elementary Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems, New York: J. Wiley, latest ed.

title: Abstract Algebra
description: This course is an introduction to modern abstract algebra, focusing on groups and rings. It is a continuation of MATH2070. Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070, or equivalent.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: We introduce the students to the some basic concepts of abstract algebra and get a flavor of the modern theoretical mathematics, and enable them to produce rigorous mathematical proofs based on abstract theory on their own. Upon completion of the course, students should be able to - learn the basics of group theory: normal subgroups, quotient groups, direct products, structure of finitely generated abelian groups, group action, Cayley's theorem, Sylow theorems; - learn the basics of ring theory: prime and maximal ideals, polynomial rings, factorization in integral domains, principal ideal domains, unique factorization domains; - apply basic results and techniques to solve problems in the theory and other related subjects; - prepare for further studies in algebra-related subjects.
syllabus: Group theory: normal subgroups, quotient groups, direct products, structure of finitely generated abelian groups, group action, Cayley's theorem, Sylow theorems. Ring theory: prime and maximal ideals, polynomial rings, factorization in integral domains, principal ideal domains, unique factorization domains.
recommended_readings: A First Course in Abstract Algebra, by J. B. Fraleigh Algebra, by M. Artin Algebra, by T. W. Hungerford Abstract Algebra, by D. S. Dummit and R. M. Foote

title: Fields and Galois Theory
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH3030.
description: This course is an introduction to the theory of field extensions and Galois theory. It is one of the continuations of MATH3030 (the other being MATH4080). Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070 and MATH3030, or equivalent.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: We introduce the students to the advanced level of abstract algebra so that they are able to appreciate the exciting development of abstract algebra since the mid 19th century. And we provide the students with a solid background to understand deep mathematics and make them well-prepared for more advanced topics like: number theory, representation theory, algebraic geometry. Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  - learn the basics of field extension: algebraic extensions, algebraic closures, geometric constructions, finite fields; - learn the basics of Galois theory: splitting fields, separable and inseparable extensions, Galois extensions, Galois correspondences, cyclotomic extensions, solvability by radicals; - apply basic results and techniques to solve problems in the theory and other related subjects; - prepare for graduate studies in algebra-related subjects such as algebraic geometry, algebraic number theory and representation theory.
syllabus: Topics include: field extensions, algebraic extensions, algebraic closures, geometric constructions, finite fields, splitting fields, separable and inseparable extensions, Galois extensions, Galois correspondences, cyclotomic extensions, solvability by radicals, etc.
recommended_readings: A First Course in Abstract Algebra, by J. B. Fraleigh Algebra, by M. Artin Algebra, by T. W. Hungerford Abstract Algebra, by D. S. Dummit and R. M. Foote

title: Mathematical Analysis III
description: This course is a continuation of MATH2060. It provides rigorous treatment on further topics in mathematical analysis. This course is essential for studying advanced mathematics, pure or applied, to the level beyond undergraduate. Topics include: Fourier series, pointwise and uniform convergence of Fourier series, $L^2$-completeness of Fourier series. Parseval's identity; metric spaces, open sets and continuity, completion of a metric space, contraction mapping principle; the space of continuous functions, Weierstrass approximation theorem, Stone-Weierstrass theorem, Baire category theorem, continuous but nowhere differentiable functions, equicontinuity and Ascoli's theorem; implicit and inverse function theorems, functional dependence and independence; fundamental existence and uniqueness theorem for differential equations, the continuous dependence of the solution on initial time and values.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: After taking this course, a student will be able to 1. how to expand a function into a Fourier series and under what conditions the Fourier series converges to the function, 2. describe to describe limit and continuity in terms of open sets in a metric space, 3. use the contraction principle to solve some equations, 4. apply the fundamental results such as Stone-Weierstrass theorem, Baire category theorem and Ascoli's theorem in his/her further studies in analysis, 5. understand the proofs of the implicit and inverse function theorem and many of their applications, and 6. the details in the proof of the fundamental existence and uniqueness of differential equations, a theorem stated in MATH3270.
syllabus: Fourier series, pointwise and uniform convergence of Fourier series, $L^2$-completeness of Fourier series. Parseval's identity; metric spaces, open sets and continuity, completion of a metric space, contraction mapping principle, existence and uniqueness of the fundamental theorem of differential equations; the space of continuous functions, Weierstrass approximation theorem, Stone-Weierstrass theorem, Baire category theorem, continuous but nowhere differentiable functions, equicontinuity and Ascoli's theorem; Implicit and inverse function theorems, functional dependence and independence; the continuous dependence of the solution on initial time and values.
recommended_readings: - Fourier Series, G P Tolstov, Dover Publication, New York. - Topology, 2nd ed., J R Munkres, Prentice Hill, New Jersey. - Foundation of Modern Analysis, J. Dieudonne, Academic Press, New York.

title: Introduction to Topology
description: Topological Space: open set, closed set, compact set, limit pint, Heine-Borel Theorem, continuous map, homeomorphism, connectedness, metric space, group action on a topological space and quotient topology. Fundamental Group: loop, space of loops, homotopy, calculation of fundamental groups of some spaces, path lifting lemma, homotopy lifting lemma, fundamental groups of quotient spaces of free discrete group actions.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students understand the concepts listed in the course content.
syllabus: Topological Space: open set, closed set, compact set, limit pint, Heine-Borel Theorem, continuous map, homeomorphism, connectedness, metric space, group action on a topological space, quotient topology. Fundamental Group: loop, space of loop, homotopy, calculation of fundamental groups of some spaces, path lifting lemma, homotopy lifting lemma, fundamental groups of quotient spaces of free discrete group actions.
recommended_readings: - Davis, Topology, Mc-Graw Hill - Armstrong, Basic Topology, Springer - Munkres, Topology, 2nd Edition, Pearson

title: Number Theory
description: This course is intended to introduce the students to the intriguing structure of integers. Topics are usually selected from: divisibility theory of the integers, primes, congruence, Fermat's little theorem, some arithmetic functions, primitive roots and indices.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: - Students learn basic concepts and results about divisibility of integers, including greatest common divisor, Euclid’s algorithm, fundamental theorem of arithmetic, properties of primes. - Students learn some typical arithmetic functions and learn the Mobius inversion formulae, learn some properties of the Riemann zeta-function. - Students learn some fundamental results about congruence, such as Chinese remainder theorem, Fermat, Euler, Lagrange’s theorems; and learn how to solve linear congruence equations; learn the concepts and properties of primitive roots and indices. - Students learn some concepts and results about quadratic residues, such as Legendre symbol, Jacobi’s symbol and law of quadratic reciprocity; learn how to solve quadratic congruence equations. - Students learn some elementary results on quadratic forms: the representations of integers by binary forms, in particular the representation of integers as the sum of squares.
syllabus: Topics are usually selected from: divisibility theory of the integers, primes, congruence, Fermat’s little theorem, some arithmetic functions, primitive roots and indices.

title: Fourier Analysis
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH2060/2068.
description: This course is an introduction to Fourier series and Fourier transform. Topics include: Orthogonal families of functions, mean-square convergence of Fourier series and completeness, pointwise convergence of Fourier series, Gibbs's phenomenon; Fourier transform and its inversion, Plancherel formula. Further topics will be selected from: The isoperimetric inequality, Poisson summation formula Heisenberg uncertainty principle, and the notion of a wavelet.

title: Operations Research
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH3210 or MATH3220. Pre-requisite: MATH1030/1038.
description: Operations Research (OR) refers to the science of decision making. It uses various problem-solving techniques and methods to analyse system behavior and improve decision-making and efficiency by arriving at optimal or near optimal solutions to complex decision problems. This course provides a fundamental account of the basic results and techniques of Linear Programming (LP), network optimization and integer programming in Operations Research. There is an equal emphasis on all three aspects of theory, algorithms as well as applications, which provides essential optimization concept and background for more advanced studies in Operations Research. Students are expected to have basic knowledge in linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students should be able to  - develop a theoretical understanding in fundamental concept and approach of Operations research appropriate to the further study; - formulate a real-world problem as an appropriate mathematical programming model; - implement algorithms/methods of operations research in solving problems on mathematical programming; - critically analyse and interpret results on the practical level.
syllabus: A wide array topics will be covered, including linear programming and simplex method, as well as related analytical topics. It will also introduce other types of mathematical models, including transportation problems, network problems, integer programming, and so on.
required_readings: None. The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
recommended_readings: Operations Research: An Introduction, by H.F. Taha Introduction to Operations Research, by F.S. Hillier and G.J. Lieberman Linear and Nonlinear Programming, by D.G. Luenberger and Y.Y. Ye Introduction to Linear Optimization, by D. Bertsimas and J.N. Tsitsiklis

title: Numerical Analysis
description: Floating-point numbers and roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations, solutions of nonlinear equations, linear systems, interpolation, numerical differentiation, and numerical integration. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to understand the fundamental concepts involved in numerical analysis, and learn some basic approaches and techniques in solving linear and nonlinear systems, constructing interpolations and do numerical differntiation and integration. The basic learning outcomes include: - Students understand the basic concepts in scientific computings, including fixed-point numbers, floating-point numbers, single and double precision, overflow and underflow, roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations. - Students learn some basic knowledge in floating-point arithmetic and know how to use the backward error analysis to estimate possible errors generated in numerical computings. - Students learn some basic concepts in solving nonlinear equations of one variable: iterative methods, rate of convergence, local and global convergence; learn some classical methods for solving nonlinear equations of one variable: bisection methods, Newton's method, quasi-Newton's method and fixed-point iteration, and learn how to analyse convergence of these method. - Students learn some basic methods for solving linear system of equations: Cholesky factorization, LU and LDU factorization, forward- and backward-substitutions for traingular systems, Gaussian elimination. - Students learn sensitivity analysis of the solutions of linear systems with respect to some errors in their coefficient matrices or in their right-hand sides, and understand condition numbers and their importance. - Students learn three polynomial interpolations, Newton form of interpolations, Lagrange and spline interpolations, and learn how to estimate the interpolation errors. - Students learn some popular numerical integrations: trapezoidal and composite trapezoidal rules, Simpson and composite Simpson rules, Newton-Cotes quadrature rule, Gaussian quadrature rules, and learn how to estimate the errors of quadrature rules. - Students learn some basic numerical differentiation techniques: forward differences, backward differences, central differences, and understand how to estimate the errors of these difference schemes.
syllabus: Floating-point numbers and roundoff errors, absolute and relative errors, stable and unstable computations, solutions of nonlinear equations, linear systems, interpolation, numerical differentiation, numerical integration.
recommended_readings: Main Reference: - D. Kincaid & W. Cheney, Numerical Analysis: Mathematics of Scientific Computing, Brooks/Cole Publishing Co., New York - G.W. Stewart, Afternotes on Numerical Analysis, SIAM Other References: - R. L. Burden and J. D. Faires, Numerical Analysis, Brooks/Cole-Thomson Learning - C.F. Gerald and P.O. Wheatley, Applied Numerical Analysis, Person Addison Wesley - G.H. Golub and C.F. van Loan, Matrix computations, Johns Hopkins University Press, MD

title: Numerical Methods for Differential Equations
description: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, numerical solution of partial differential equations. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to understand some fundamental concepts involved in numerical methods for differential equations, and learn some basic approaches and techniques in solving ordinary and partial differential equations. The basic learning outcomes include: - Students understand the importance of differential equations in modeling real-world phenomena and understand the meanings and importance of numerical methods in solving general ordinary and partial differential equations. - Students learn some basic mathematical method of verifying the well-posedness of a ordinary differential equation (ODE). - For a given first order ODE, students learn how to construct Taylor-series methods and Runge-Kutta methods with orders up to four. - Students learn some basic approaches to constructing multistep methods: the quadrature rule approach, test function approach by polynomials, Adams-Bashforth and Adams-Mouton methods. And learn how to solve ODEs using multistep methods and predictor-corrector methods. - Students learn how to compute the orders of multistep methods, and how to analyse consistency, stability and convergence of multistep methods and understand the relationship between these three concepts. - Students learn how to convert a higher order ODE into a system of first order ODEs and how to construct Taylor-series methods and Runge-Kutta methods for the resulting ODE system. - Students learn some important numerical methods for solving stiff ODEs, and understand the importance of A-stability, absolute stability and regions of absolute stability. - Students learn how to use the shooting method to transform a two-point boundary value problem into an initial value problem. - Students learn some basic finite difference schemes and collocation methods to solve two-point boundary value problems. - Students learn some basic finite difference schemes to solve the one- and two-dimensional parabolic equations, and know how to analyse the consistency, stability and convergence of a finite difference scheme. - Students learn some simple finite element methods to solve the one- and two-dimensional parabolic equations.
syllabus: Numerical solution of ordinary differential equations, numerical solution of partial differential equations.

title: Discrete Mathematics
description: This is an introductory course of discrete mathematics. Topics will be chosen from: set theory and logic, algorithms, number theory, information theory, algebraic structures, combinatorics, probability, calculus and finite difference, discrete and computational geometry, graph theory, automata theory, game theory.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Graph Theory
description: Definitions and applications of graphs and digraphs, Eulerian graphs, Hamiltonian graphs, path algorithm, connectivity, trees, planarity and coloring graphs.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Ordinary Differential Equations
description: Ordinary differential equations arise from quantitative description of natural and social phenomena. Topics are: method of explicit solution, linear equations and systems, series solutions, Sturm-Liouville boundary value problems, dynamical systems and stability, applications to mechanics, electrical networks and population of species.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: After taking and passing this course, a student should be able - to solve first or second order ODE’s by elementary methods such as change of variables and power series expansion, - to understand the structure theory of linear systems of equations, - on the theoretical side, to master the proof of the fundamental theorem on existence and uniqueness of solution to a general ODE, and - to understand the basic concept of stability of a solution including some examples arising from mathematical biology. - to know the set-up of the Sturm-Liouville boundary value problems.
syllabus: Ordinary differential equations arise from quantitative description of natural and social phenomena. Topics are: methods of explicit solution, linear equations and systems, series solutions, Sturm-Liouville boundary value problems, dynamical systems and stability, applications to mechanics, electrical networks and population of species.

title: Introductory Probability
requirements: Not for students who have taken MIEG2440/ESTR2362.
description: Axioms of probability, conditional probability, independence, discrete random variables, continuous random variables, mean, variance and covariance, moment generating function, Poisson distributions, normal distributions, central limit theorem, law of large numbers, random walks, transition probabilities and Markov chains. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students learn the basic concepts of probability. They include: conditional probability, random variables, distributions, expectation and Limit theorems. Also students learn their applications in physical science and engineering.
syllabus: Axioms of probability, conditional probability, independence, discrete random variables, continuous random variables, mean, variance and covariance, moment generating function, Poisson distributions, normal distributions, central limit theorem, law of large numbers, random walks, transition probabilities and Markov chains.
recommended_readings: - S. Ghahramani, Fundamentals of Probability, Prentice Hall

title: Mathematical Modeling
description: This course introduces the concept of mathematical modeling. Topics include: different modeling techniques such as modeling with differential equations and modeling with linear programming, forecasting; economic models such as Markov models, network models and financial models such as input-output models and scheduling models.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Computational and Applied Mathematics
description: This course introduces the general solution methods used in computational and applied mathematics. The central topics are differential equations and matrix equations. Methods include Fourier series, orthogonal expansion, conformal mapping, Fourier integrals, complex integration, LU decomposition, Newton method, semi-direct and iterative methods, the finite element methods and fast Fourier transform. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to learn some general mathematical methods which are frequently used in computational and applied mathematics, as well as in the physics and engineering applications. The basic learning outcomes include:  - Students learn some basic techniques of solving two-point elliptic boundary value problems (BVPs), and understand how to formulate a BVP into an equivalent minimization problem and an equivalent variational problem. - Students learn some basic vector calculus in Euclidiean space, including gradient, divergence and vorticity operations, and know how to express a differential equation in the rectangular coordinate system, cylindrical coordinate system and spherical coordinate system. - Students learn how to compute a real and complex Fourier series for a given periodic function, and understand the relation between the real and complex Fourier series. - Students learn how to solve some standard differential equations in certain nice domains, like Laplace equation in a unit disk, by using the Fourier series. - Students learn how to construct a series of orthonormal polynomial functions by Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process. - Students learn how to find the Fourier and inverse Fourier transforms, as well as the discrete Fourier transform for a given function. - Students learn the LU factorization for a given matrix and its relation with Gaussian elimination. - Students learn how to solve nonlinear systems of equations by Newton's method, and how to solve linear systems of equations by Jacobi, Gauss-Seidal and successive overrelaxation methods, and understand why these methods work or do not work for some linear or nonlinear systems. - Students learn how to find the eigenvalues of a matrix by QR factorization and understand the mathematics behind. - Students learn the fast Fourier transform and its applications. - Students learn how to solve a two-point boundary value problem by a simple finite element method.
syllabus: This course introduces the general solution methods used in computational and applied mathematics. The central topics are differential equations and matrix equations. Methods include Fourier series, orthogonal expansion, conformal mapping, Fourier integrals, complex integration, LU decomposition, Newton method, semi-direct and iterative methods, the finite element methods and fast Fourier transform. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and linear algebra.

title: Foundation of Data Analytics
description: This course gives an introduction to computational data analytics, with emphasis on its mathematical foundations. The goal is to carefully develop and explore mathematical theories and methods that make up the backbone of modern mathematical data sciences, such as knowledge discovery in databases, machine learning, and mathematical artificial intelligence. Topics include mathematical foundations of probability, linear approximation and its polynomial and high dimensional extensions, proper orthogonal decomposition methods, optimization, theories of nonlinear neural network and approximations. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge of basic linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Learning outcomes:  On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Understand in-depth the various topics in modern data analysis and the technical difficulties in solving them • Acquire knowledge about the foundation of computational data analytics • Learn how to use various mathematical models to extract important information from big data  • Systematically evaluate the performance of different models to solve various data analysis problems • Understand the importance of computational data analytics for real-world problems
syllabus: Cover various topics related to computational data analytics, including mathematical foundations of probability, linear approximation and its polynomial and high dimensional extensions, proper orthogonal decomposition methods, optimization, theories of nonlinear neural network and approximations.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.

title: Big Data Computing
requirements: Pre-requisite: CSCI1540.
description: This course provides students with practical experience in using mathematical techniques for big data computing, numerical optimization and simulations of practical mathematical models through various programming and software implementation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in mathematical foundation of data analytics. Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Acquire practical experiences in big data computing • Use of common software packages for big data computing • Learn how to use mathematical machine learning algorithms to solve problems • Design solution strategies using sophisticated mathematical modelling and computational techniques for real life applications
syllabus: Cover mathematical techniques for big data computing, numerical optimization and simulations of practical mathematical models through various programming and software implementation.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.

title: Mathematical Imaging
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH1030/1038, MATH2010/2018 and MATH2221.
description: This course gives an introducion on mathematical models and techniques for various image processing tasks. A wide array of topics will be covered, including image restoration (denoising, deblurring), image decomposition, image segmentation, image registration, feature detection, multi-scale image analysis, morphology and so on. Students will become familiar with essential mathematical techniques for imaging tasks, such as image processing in the spatial domain (using gradient, Laplacian, convolution) and frequency domain (using Fourier / wavelet transform). Variational models and PDE-based techniques will also be discussed.Students are expected to have basic knowledge in calculus, linear algebra and MATLAB language. Some background in numerical analysis, Fourier analysis and partial differential equations will be helpful, although the necessary concepts will be discussed as they are used.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Functional Analysis
description: Metric spaces, fixed point theorems, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, continuous linear operator, the Hahn-Banach extension theorem, the uniform boundedness principle and the open mapping theorem, and applications of the above topics. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: This is an advanced undergraduate course. We expect students to understand how linear algebra and analysis can be put together to become one of the most important fields of mathematics; we also emphasize the generality and depth of this treatment as a useful tool in many other disciplines and for graduate study. - Students are expected to know the distance concept in metric spaces, and point set topology such as open sets and close sets, convergence, Cauchy sequences, completion, continuity. - Students learn the concept of norm linear spaces, Banach spaces, compactness of finite dimensional spaces, bounded linear operators, functionals and dual spaces. - Students learn inner product spaces, Hilbert spaces, orthogonality and direct sums. These concepts will be used in Fourier series and other classical orthogonal series. - Students learn the Reiesz representation theorem on Hilbert space and use it to define the adjoint operators. An elementary theory on self-adjoint operator will be developed. - Students learn the fundamental theorems for normed linear spaces: the Hahn-Banach theorem and its applications to the Reiesz representation theorem on continuous function space, the uniform boundedness principle, the open mapping theorem. The concept of strong and weak convergence will be introduced. - Students learn how to solve some standard differential equations in certain nice domains, like Laplace equation in a unit disk, by using the Fourier series. - Students learn how to construct a series of orthonormal polynomial functions by Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization process. - Students learn how to find the Fourier and inverse Fourier transforms, as well as the discrete Fourier transform for a given function. - Students learn the LU factorization for a given matrix and its relation with Gaussian elimination. - Students learn how to solve nonlinear systems of equations by Newton's method, and how to solve linear systems of equations by Jacobi, Gauss-Seidal and successive overrelaxation methods, and understand why these methods work or do not work for some linear or nonlinear systems. - Students learn how to find the eigenvalues of a matrix by QR factorization and understand the mathematics behind. - Students learn the fast Fourier transform and its applications. - Students learn how to solve a two-point boundary value problem by a simple finite element method.
syllabus: Metric spaces, fixed point theorems, Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, continuous linear operator, the Hahn-Banach extension theorem, the uniform boundedness principle and the open mapping theorem, and applications of the above topics. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and linear algebra.

Simons, McGraw-Hill - Real Analysis, H. Royden, Macmillian - Real and Complex Analysis, W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill - Functional Analysis, W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill

title: Calculus of Variations
description: This course is intended to provide a basic theory of calculus of variations. Topics are usually selected from: necessary condition for extremum, Euler equation, fixed end point problem for unknown functions involving higher-order derivatives, natural boundary condition and transversality, Weierstrass-Erdman corner conditions, and sufficient conditions. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Differential Geometry
requirements: Not for students who have taken MATH4033.
description: This course covers basic theory on curves, and surfaces in the Euclidean three space. Topics include: regular curves, Frenet formulas, local theory of curves, global properties of curves such as isoperimetric inequality, regular surfaces, 1st and 2nd fundamental form, Gaussian curvature and mean curvature, Gauss map, special surfaces such as ruled surfaces, surfaces of revolution, minimal surfaces, intrinsic geometry: geodesic, and Gauss-Bonnet Theorem. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus, linear algebra, and elementary differential equations.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: - Students learn ways to describe curves and surfaces in space, by equations and parametrizations. - Students learn the differential approach to regular geometric objects, using moving frames and searching for complete local invariants. In particular, they learn the Frenet frame, curvature and torsion of regular space curves. - Students use integration techniques to study some global theorems on plane curves and methods of ordinary differential equations to obtain curves with prescribed curvature and torsion. - Students learn the formulation of regular surfaces in 3 dimensions, their orientability, differentiable structure and metric structure. - Students learn the Gauss map and its many important consequences. - Students learn computations of various curvatures through examples and special surfaces.
syllabus: Topics include: regular curves, Frenet formulas, local theory of curves, global properties of curves such as isoperimetric inequality, regular surfaces, 1st and 2nd fundamental form, Gaussian curvature and mean curvature, Gauss map, special surfaces such as ruled surfaces, surfaces of revolution, minimal surfaces, intrinsic geometry: geodesics and Gauss-Bonnet Theorem.
recommended_readings: References: - M.P. do Carmo, Differential Geometry of Curves and Surfaces, Prentice Hall - B. O’Neill, Elementary Differential Geometry, Academic Press - J.J. Stoker, Differential Geometry, Wiley - J. Opera, Differential Geometry and Its Applications, 2nd Edition, Pearson

title: Real Analysis
description: This is an introductory course on the Lebesgue integration theory on real line. Topics include: measurable sets, measurable functions, Lebesgue integral, Fatou's lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem and differentiation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: - Students learn the basic properties of measurable sets and measurable functions on the real line. - Students learn the introduction of Lebesgue integration and its basic properties. - Students learn the fundamental convergence theorems including Fatou's lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominate convergence theorem and results in connection with differentiation.
syllabus: Topics include: measurable sets, measurable functions, Lebesgue integral, Fatou’s lemma, monotone convergence theorem, Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem and differentiation. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis.
recommended_readings: - H.L. Royden, Real Analysis (3rd Ed), Prentice Hall - W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, McGraw Hill - E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Real and Abstract Analysis, Springer-Verlag - K. R. Davidson and A. Donsig, Real Analysis with Real Applications, Prentice Hall

title: Complex Analysis
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH2230 or MATH3253.
description: This course is designed for students who are intending to acquire advanced theoretical understanding about analytic functions, which is typically needed for further studies. The course emphasizes the rigorous treatment of the analysis of complex functions. Students are expected to have sophisticated mathematics background and superb theoretical knowledge in multivariable calculus. Major topics include entire functions of infinite series and infinite products, normal families, theory of conformal mappings. Details are given in course syllabus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students will be able to state and prove important theorems about analytic functions, including sequence or series of functions, local and global theories.
syllabus: 1. Quick review of functions of one complex variable. 2. Jensen’s formula, infinite products, Hadamard’s Theorem, Gamma and Zeta functions. 3. Normal families, Arzela-Ascoli’s Theorem. 4. Conformal mappings, Schwarz lemma, Riemann Mapping Theorem, mappings of polygons. 5. Optional topics selected from  a. Dirichlet problems, harmonic and subharmonic functions  b. Famous examples of elliptic functions  c. Analytic continuation and monodromy  d. Basic Riemann surfaces
recommended_readings: • Ellias Stein and Rami Shakarchi: Complex Analysis. Princeton University Press. • Lars V. Ahlfors: Complex Analysis. McGraw Hill. • Tristan Needham: Visual Complex Analysis. Oxford University Press. • Walter Rudin: Real and Complex Analysis. McGraw Hill.

title: Modules and Representation Theory
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH3030.
description: This course is an introduction to modules over rings, as well as the representation theory of finite groups. It is one of the continuations of MATH3030 (the other being MATH3040). Students are expected to have knowledge in MATH2070 and MATH3030, or equivalent.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Financial Mathematics
description: Topics of this course will include: Basic option theory, forward and futures contracts, model of asset price, Ito's Lemma, asset price random walk, Black-Scholes model, free boundary problems of options, constrained matrix problems and the projected SOR method, discrete random walk model and the binomial methods.
