title: Partial Differential Equations
description: This is an introduction to the classical theory of partial differential equations. Topics are usually selected from: First-order equations, types of second-order equations, well-posedness of the wave and the heat equations, boundary value problems for the Laplace and Poisson equations, separation of variables. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: In general, the goal is to let the student understand the basic properties of the three principal types- hyperbolic, elliptic and parabolic equations. After taking and passing this course, a student is expected - to distinguish the types of the equations and use change of variables to simplify them,  - to solve well-posed problems by the method of separation of variables. (In particular, he/she should be able to use this method to solve the mixed problems including one-dimensional wave and heat equations as well as the boundary value problems for the Laplace equation on a disk.) - on the theoretical side, to know how the method of separation of variables is related to eigenvalue problems. (Rigorous proofs of convergence of the series of solutions should also be understood.) - to learn well the solution of the Cauchy problem for the wave equations in low dimensions by the method of spherical means, - to learn well the solution of the Cauchy problem for the heat equation by the heat kernel or by Fourier transform. The characteristic properties of heat flows and wave motions should be well-understood. - to know the Poison formula for the solution of the Laplace equation on a ball and have some idea of solving the problem over a general domain by Perron’s method, and  - to understand well various maximum principle as they are applied to the uniqueness issues for elliptic and parabolic equations.
syllabus: Topics are usually selected from: First-order equations, types of second-order equations, well-posedness of the wave and the heat equations, boundary value problems for the Laplace and Poisson equations, separation of variables.
recommended_readings: References (The first one is the main reference.) - Partial Differential Equations An introduction, by W.A. Strauss, John-Wiley & Sons, New York. (Easy to read. Contain many standard materials and exercises.) - A First Course in Partial Differential Equations with Complex and Transform Methods, by H. Weinberger, Dover Books on Mathematics. (This book is good source on separation of variables. Many work-out examples.) - Partial Differential Equations, 4th ed. by F. John, Springer-Verlag, New York. (A classic by a master. But a little bit difficult to read.) - Partial Differential Equations, by L.C. Evans, vol 19, Graduate Studies in Mathematics, American Mathematical Society, Providence. (Containing both linear and nonlinear theories, this is by far the best introductory book on PDE’s in postgraduate level. All proofs are rigorous and complete. The first several chapters can be read for good students in this class.)

title: Optimization Theory
description: Unconstrained and equality optimization models, constrained problems, optimality conditions for constrained extrema, convex sets and functions, duality in nonlinear convex programming, descent methods, conjugate direction methods and quasi-Newton methods. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: Students are expected to learn the basic optimization theory and concepts with emphasis on their mathematical aspects. Upon completion of the course, students are expected to:  1. learn the basic mathematical concepts and techniques for optimization;  2. be aware of the important role of mathematics in optimization;  3. appreciate the importance of optimization theory in the real world;  4. learn how to design optimization models for real-world problems; 5. implement algorithms/methods in solving problems on optimization.
syllabus: Unconstrained and equality optimization models, constrained problems, optimality conditions for constrained extrema, convex sets and functions, duality in nonlinear convex programming, descent methods, conjugate direction methods and quasi-Newton methods.

title: Stochastic Processes
requirements: Not for students who have taken IERG3300.
description: Bernoulli processes and sum of independent random variables, Poisson processes, times of arrivals, Markov chains, transient and recurrent states, stationary distribution of Markov chains, Markov pure jump processes, and birth and death processes. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in probability.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: This is a second course in probability theory. We expect students to learn systems which vary in time in a random manner. In the course they will learn the use of probability and mathematics in the theory and to see many examples that are related to real life problems. The basic learning outcomes are: - Students will be familiar with the basic probability notations: independence, conditioning, random variables, distributions, expected values, moments. - Students learn the important concept of Markov chain, transition probability, hitting time, transient and recurrent states. They will learn the computation techniques in linear analysis, and examples like gambler’s ruin problem, birth and death chains, branching chains, queuing chains. - Students learn the stationary distribution, existence and uniqueness, convergence and long time behavior, applications to real life problems. - Students learn the continuous-time Markov chains, basic properties, generator of the chains, differential equation technique, Poisson processes, birth and death processes queuing chains. - Students learn the Gaussian processes and Brownian motions.
syllabus: Bernoulli processes and sum of independent random variables, Poisson processes, times of arrivals, Markov chains, transient and recurrent states, stationary distribution of Markov chains, Markov pure jump processes, and birth and death processes. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in probability.

title: Game Theory
description: Principles and techniques of game theory, matrix games, minimax theorem and calculation of optimal strategies, cooperative and non-cooperative solutions of bimatrix games, coalitional games and applications. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in linear algebra.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.
outcome: We expect the students to understand the mathematics and quantitative techniques behind the game theory. The theory will be illustrated by plenty of examples. Through this students will be exposed to practical problem decision making and in economics including optimization, bargaining, cooperation, coalition and voting strategies. The basic learning outcomes are: - Students understand the basic step of games: the game tree, games with chances, information set, strategies, payoffs, equilibrium of strategies. - Students learn the basic mathematics and examples in two person zero-sum games: saddle point, mixed strategy, minimax theorem. They need to sue matrix theory and linear programming to solve the problems. - Students learn the non-zero sum games which includes cooperative, non-cooperative games, Nash’s equilibrium and Nash’s axiom of bargaining and the mathematics to attack these problems. - Students learn the N-person cooperative games including strategy for coalition, Shapley value, voting games.
syllabus: Principles and techniques of game theory, matrix games, minimax theorem and calculation of optimal strategies, cooperative and non-cooperative solutions of bimatrix games, coalitional games and applications.

title: Coding Theory and Cryptography
description: Coding theory: information theory, linear codes, cyclic codes and geometric codes. Cryptography: classical cryptosystems and public key cryptosystems. Students taking this course are expected to have some knowledge in algebra and number theory.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Innovation and Design in Big Data Analytics
requirements: Pre-requisite: MATH3320 and 3330.
description: This course focuses on the applications of mathematical data analytic tools in a variety of science, medical, financial and engineering problems. Students will become familiar with mathematical tools and models for essential topics/case-studies selected from, but not limited to, algorithm trading, fraud detection, digital advertising, medical imaging, bioinformatics, remote sensing, and social networks. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in mathematical foundation of data analytics and related computational techniques.Advisory: MATH Majors should select not more than 5 MATH courses in a term.

title: Real Analysis I
requirements: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics, also available to undergraduate students majored in mathematics.
description: This course is an introduction to real analysis on abstract spaces. The following contents are covered: Integration on a measure space, the construction of measures from outer measures, Riesz representation theorem relating positive functionals to measures, Lebesque and Hausdorff measures, Lebesgue spaces and their duality, weak convergence of functions, signed measures and Radon-Nikodym theorem.Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in Lebesgue integration on the real line and elements of functional analysis.
outcome: 1. To understand the modern theory of measure and integration and the functional properties of measurable functions. 2. To familiarize the skills in analysis. 3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the subject of analysis in major research universities.
syllabus: Topics include the followings: Abstract measure theory and integration of measurable functions. Various fundamental theorems concerning convergence of integrals. Outer measures and the construction of a measure space from them. Riesz representation on a locally compact Hausdorff space. Lebesgue and Hausdorff measures on the Euclidean space. The Lebesgue spaces and their functional properties, uniform convexity and duality theorem. Weak convergence of functions. Signed measures, decomposition of measures and Radon-Nikodym theorem.

recommended_readings: - W. Rudin, Real and Complex Analysis, 3rd ed. W. Rudin, McGraw-Hill, New York 1966. - L. C. Evans and R. F. Gariepy, Measure Theory and Fine Properties of Functions, revised ed. CRC Press 2015. - E.M. Stein and R. Shakarchi, Real Analysis: Measure Theory, Integration and Hilbert Spaces, Princeton Lectures in Analysis, Princeton 2005. - E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Real and Abstract Analysis, E. Hewitt and K. Stromberg, Graduate Texts in Mathematics, Springer-Verlag, New York 1975.

title: Real Analysis II
requirements: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics, also available to undergraduate students majored in mathematics.
description: This course is a sequel to MATH5011 Real Anlaysis I. It consists of two parts. In the first part we discuss various covering lemmas and their applications to differentiation theory, maximal operators, product measures, Fubini's theorem and applications, Fourier transform and the inversion theorem. The second part is an introduction to Sobolev spaces. Basic knowledge of these spaces is covered.

title: Theory of Partial Differential Equations
requirements: For M.Phil. or Ph.D. students in Division of Mathematics
description: This course covers the basic theory of partial differential equations equations with emphasis on elliptic equations of second order. Both the classical and modern approaches to these equations are discussed. The main concern is various a prior estimates which are useful in solving linear and nonlinear equations. Some geometric applications are included. It is suited for those who are interested in analysis or geometry.
outcome: The basic elliptic theory enables students to understand research papers involving elliptic equations and geometric analysis as well as equips them with necessary tools to embark on their own research.
syllabus: Classic theory: Poisson equation and Newtonian potential, maximum principles, Schauder estimates, method of continuity. DeGorgi-Nash-Moser iteration, a priori estimates, regularity theory.  Modern theory: Sobolev spaces,$W^{2,p}$-estimates, regularity of weak solutions.  Selected applications to geometry including harmonic maps.
required_readings: L. Ambrosio, Lectures on Elliptic Differential Equations  http://cvgmt.sns.it/media/doc/paper/1280/PDEAAA.pdf
recommended_readings: F.H. Lin and Q. Han, Elliptic Differential Equations, CIMS Notes.  D. Gilbarg and N.S. Trudinger, Elliptic Differential Equations of Second order, 2nd ed. Springer-Verlag.

title: Complex Analysis I

Topics include: properties of holomorphic functions, complex integration, conformal mappings, singularities and residues. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in advanced calculus and elementary analysis.

title: Topology of Manifolds
requirements: For research postgraduate students under Division of Mathematics, also available to undergraduate students majored in mathematics.
description: This course is an introduction to several basic topological invariants for manifolds. Major topics are: topological and differentiable manifolds, maps between manifolds, Sard's Theorem, degree of maps and vector fields, fundamental group, covering space, simplices and homology group, differential forms and cohomology group. Students taking this course are expected to have knowledge in elementary analysis and basic topology and algebra.
outcome: 1. To recognize the definitions and properties of several basic topological invariants for manifolds. 2. To be ready for further studies related to manifolds (smooth, Riemannian, or complex). 3. To have prepared for written qualifying examinations in the area of topology for major research universities in the world.
syllabus: There may be several focus of the course, differential topology, or algebraic topology, or a more geometric approach. Topics are selected from the following. Topological and differentiable manifolds with or without boundary, tangent bundle and vector bundle and differential forms, mappings between manifolds and differentials, Sard’s Theorem, embedding and transversality, degree of maps and vector fields, homotopy, fundamental groups, covering spaces, singular homology or de Rham cohomology.

title: Advanced Numerical Analysis I
requirements: For MPhil-PhD Mathematics
description: This course covers basic numerical methods in the graduate level. The main themes are numerical solutions of PDEs and iterative methods for linear systems. For numerical solutions of PDEs, some basic theories of finite element methods for elliptic and parabolic equations are discussed. The topics include Sobolev spaces, embedding and trace theorems, variational formulation, Lax-Milgram theorem, finite element spaces and their interpolation theories, convergence in H1 and L2 norms. For iterative methods for linear systems, the topics include Richardson, Jacobi, Gauss-Seidel and SOR methods, Krylov subspace methods, conjugate gradient method, preconditioning techniques, convergence theories, GMRES method.

title: Advanced Numerical Analysis II
requirements: For MPhil-PhD Mathematics
description: This course covers basic numerical methods in the graduate level. The main themes are numerical solutions of PDEs and numerical methods for eigenvalue problems. For numerical solutions of PDEs, some basic theories of finite difference methods for hyperbolic equations are discussed. The topics include stability, order of accuracy, consistency, Lax-equivalence theorem, multistep methods, dissipation and dispersion, system of equations in higher dimensions, splitting schemes. For numerical methods for eigenvalue problems, the topics include the Gershgorin theorem, power iteration, inverse power iteration, Householder and Givens matrices, QR factorization, QR algorithm, singular value decomposition, principle component analysis, rank deficient problems, regularization techniques.
outcome: Students are expected to learn the basic theories of finite difference method for PDE as well as some classical iterative methods for linear algebraic and eigenvalue problems. The learning outcomes are - Students learn how to construct finite difference schemes for hyperbolic PDE. - Students learn how to analyze the stability by the Fourier method. - Students learn how to prove convergence and consistency. - Students learn how to construct multistep methods. - Students learn how to analyze dissipation and dispersion. - Students learn how to construct and analyze schemes for hyperbolic systems in multi-dimensions. - Students learn how to construct and analyze splitting schemes.  - Students learn some basic iterative method for eigenvalue problems, including power and inverse power iteration, as well as QR algorithm. - Students learn how to compute the Householder and Givens matrices, QR factorization and singular value decomposition, together with their applications.  - Students learn the theory and applications of principle component analysis. - Students learn how to solve rank deficient problems and their regularization techniques..
syllabus: The topics include stability, order of accuracy, consistency, Lax-equivalence theorem, multistep methods, dissipation and dispersion, system of equations in higher dimensions, splitting schemes. For numerical methods for eigenvalue problems, the topics include the Gershgorin theorem, power iteration, inverse power iteration, Householder and Givens matrices, QR factorization, QR algorithm, singular value decomposition, principle component analysis, rank deficient problems, regularization techniques.
required_readings: - Morton and Mayers, Numerical Solution of Partial Differential Equations: An Introduction, Cambridge University Press - Gene Golub and Charles Van Loan, Matrix Computations, Johns Hopkins University Press
recommended_readings: - John C. Strikwerda, Finite Difference Schemes and Partial Differential Equations, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics - Lloyd N. Trefethen and David Bau III, Numerical Linear Algebra, Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics
